Mr. Speaker, I call on the Minister of Veterans Affairs to reassure the veterans of Canada that the benefits and programs his department provides will continue as long as there are needy and disabled Canadians who need them.
Seventy-five years ago the Prime Minister of Canada promised the veterans of World War I that they would be cared for by a grateful nation. Today there is fear among the veteran population that this government is planning to abandon them and abandon the department in the name of cost efficiency.
I understand that at least 250 positions at Veterans Affairs Canada will be declared surplus under the work force adjustment program in the coming year. I further understand that the department is undertaking joint studies with Health and Welfare about the future and about amalgamation.
It is time for the government and the minister to make a clear commitment to the veterans of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased that the environment minister has chosen to follow my suggestion made last week in this House that Canada implement a ban on CFCs by 1995.
I remind the minister that it is Canada and not the provinces that must set regulations for CFC recovery. It is Canada that will negotiate changes to the Montreal protocol this coming November.
With alarming new evidence that the ozone layer is disappearing faster than anyone expected, we are in a state of environmental emergency. Now is the time for the federal government to bring in national standards for the recovery of CFCs.
Almost six months ago I suggested this government examine the CFC-sucking vampire units. With an estimated recovery market worth more than $2 billion, recovering used CFCs would create jobs in our failing

March 19, 1992
economy as well as save the ozone and protect people's health.
This government has too little courage. Instead of allocating federal resources in Canadian technology that could be exported to the rest of the world, it takes timid baby steps when giant strides are necessary.

Mr. Speaker, the recent announcement by General Motors of job cuts was a severe blow to the people of St. Catharines.
The immediate reaction to the news was naturally one of anger, resentment and anxiety about the future of the city as well as a temptation to place blame for the situation. While understandable, these emotions are not going to help our community.
Within days of the announcement there was a meeting of business people, labour leaders and individuals from all levels of government representing the three main political parties. The tone of the meeting was one of commitment to co-operate in trying to find solutions to our economic situation.
It is unfortunate that it took a problem of this magnitude to get everyone to work together, but clearly that is how we will succeed.
St. Catharines has many significant assets, but easily the best is its people. I am confident the citizens of the garden city will prosper in the face of this setback. I know we will all continue to work together to ensure our future success.

Mr. Speaker, over the past four days, the Bloc Quebecois has been struggling to amend Bill C-13, which runs directly counter to Quebec's best interest.
Yesterday, the Quebec National Assembly passed a unanimous resolution condemning this bill. Today, Premier Bourassa, the Quebec Manufacturers' Association
and the Quebec Chamber of Commerce are asking federal MPs from Quebec to kill this bill.
Here is a chance for the Conservative MPs from Quebec to fight for their homeland instead of for then-party. They must refuse to destroy Quebec's economy and to personify domineering federalism.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome the commitment by the Department of Transport to continue federal funding of the Fraser River log trap located in the heart of my constituency.
Some 11 kilometres up the Fraser River from Agassiz in my riding of Fraser Valley East the log trap clears debris from the Fraser River ensuring the safety of river traffic downstream.
There was some concern that the federal commitment to this operation would lapse. I joined my B.C. colleagues and with much perseverance we persuaded the Department of Transport to reconsider its commitment to the Fraser River Debris Control Board. As a result, the $180,000 annual federal contribution to the Fraser River Debris Control Board will be maintained for the next five years.
The debris trap collects 100,000 cubic metres of debris each year and contributes to the bulk of the board's operations. I trust that this addresses any concerns as to the federal government's commitment to navigational safety on the Fraser River.

Mr. Speaker, how insensitive and incoherent has our immigration policy become? And how unreasonable the decisions of our department of immigration and its refugee determination board? Their decisions deal with people as just so many ciphers, and Canada's reputation for understanding and humanity is suffering as a result.
The plight of the Rees family is a case in point. Reran and Gale Rees have been ideal parents of an ideal Canadian family since their arrival in this country in June 1988. Reran became a valued part of the production
March 19, 1992

team of CFM-TV, and Gale a nurse. Both are community minded volunteers. Four of their children are exemplary students as these letters of support indicate.
However their family's claim for refugee status has been denied four years later. Worse, the department has issued notices and made travel plans for all but the youngest member of the Rees family, a Canadian born two-year old. What does the minister propose to do to advance the interests of this young Canadian who will be deprived of his parents? Is it not time for the minister of immigration to become involved in the issue?

Mr. Speaker, on March 18 yet another terrorist attack was carried out by enemies of Israel, this time against the Israeli Embassy in Buenos Aires. More than 11 people were killed and over 130 wounded.
Terrorist attacks such as this do not intimidate the Jewish people. They only serve to identify the perpetrators as inhuman cowards, consumed with blind sadistic malevolence.
The Jewish community and friends of the Jewish community once again feel the searing pain of racist acts of hate and once again experience a sense of revulsion and renewed solidarity against such acts and such people.

Mr. Speaker, for some time I and many other Canadians, including members of this House, have been concerned about the plight of Christine Lamont and David Spencer.
Recently the archbishop of Sao Paulo has written to the Canadian government, to the Secretary of State for External Affairs, urging the minister to do that which is necessary in order for these two young people to be released from the terrible predicament they are in, and that is to make a formal request for their expulsion from Brazil.
The government has yet to do this. It is a strange situation where we have almost a consensus in Brazil, and particularly on the part of the church, that these people are innocent and they do not deserve what is being meted out to them in a foreign country. Yet it is their own government which refuses to act.
I hope the Prime Minister will intervene, as it has been suggested he might, and make sure that this expulsion order is given and given soon so that these young people might be returned to Canada.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, three months ago the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans made comments which were insulting and offensive to women at a fund-raising dinner on Prince Edward Island.
I, along with other groups and individuals from my province, wrote to the Prime Minister that month urging him to elicit an apology from the minister for the remarks. To date no response has been received.
Last week we acknowledged International Women's Day and the contributions women have made to our society. I feel the least the Prime Minister could do is to distance himself from the minister's comments and demand an apology.
To do less is to demonstrate that this Prime Minister is not prepared to demonstrate a serious commitment to ensuring that women are treated with dignity, respect and equality.
Let us see some leadership on this issue. Let us see if the message put forward by International Women's Day has actually been received by the government.

Mr. Speaker, Canada is in the forefront of the battle against ozone depletion.
Last August the government launched a $25 million green plan initiative to accelerate the domestic regulatory control program. Canada has reduced its consumption of CFCs by 50 per cent since 1986 and is committed to eliminate their production and import into this country no later than 1997.
The government is also working with the provinces to develop a comprehensive national action plan to promote the conservation, recovery and recycling of ozone depleting chemicals. Also the government will provide
Canadians regular updates on the status of the ozone layer and on implications for the level of the sun's ultraviolet rays.

Mr. Speaker, there was a case in Winnipeg recently where a 58-year old woman was denied a survivor's benefit. Her husband lived with another woman for a year before he died.
The Department of National Health and Welfare ruled that the other woman is entitled to the pension. In this case the man's wife lived with him for 18 years and received nothing. There was no divorce.
Had this happened prior to 1987 and there were contesting applications, the minister of health could have made a judgment on such a situation. Now an individual only has to prove that he or she has lived with another person common law and be entitled to such a pension.
Surely there must be a fairer way of settling things. Not to do so would be a callous disregard this government has shown for Canadian families and this situation in particular.

Mr. Speaker, as was announced earlier this week, Ontarians will soon enjoy a privilege previously known only in the west.
Starting in May, Ontarians will be able to purchase ethanol blend gasolines. Thanks to the forward looking partnership of Sunoco and United Co-Operatives of Ontario-you gotta love those co-operatives, Mr. Speaker-Ontarians will have a whole new market for some of their produce and Ontario consumers will be able to fuel their cars with same ethanol blends already labelled an "environmental choice" product at Mohawk Company pumps across the west.
Hundreds of thousands fewer tonnes of new carbon pulled up from underground and introduced into the biosphere every year and 30 per cent lower carbon monoxide emissions are the boon of ethanol fuels.
March 19, 1992

Congratulations, Sunoco and United Co-Ops of Ontario, and welcome to ethanol fuels, Ontarians.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Saturday, March 21 is the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination.
In 1986, Prime Minister Mulroney announced that Canada would participate in the second decade to fight racism and racial discrimination. In 1989, the federal government launched its first national March 21 campaign.
Mr. Speaker, I am proud of what my government has done and the leadership it has shown.
Together with police departments, businesses and unions, educators and academics, municipal or voluntary organizations, broadcasters and many others, we have begun the process of change so that one day, all Canadians can participate fully and on an equal footing in the life of our society, as the Prime Minister said.
Mr. Speaker, I know that all members of this House will agree with me that the sooner that day arrives, the happier and more prosperous all Canadians will be.

Mr. Speaker, in 1989 the world watched, tears of joy flowing, as the Berlin wall came tumbling down, bringing with it an end to 50 years of fear and oppression.
Now the world must turn its attention to others in need to a people who are tortured, imprisoned, humiliated and stripped of basic rights and freedoms, the Syrian Jews. Now we must bring down the walls of Syria and free the Syrian Jews from captivity.
President Hafez el-Assad is not immune to pressure. He must know that he can no longer hold 4,000 people hostage in their own country. Nor can he track their every move with secret police or imprison them without charge.
Oral Questions
Let us send a clear message to our government that it must become a link in the armour against anti-Semitism. Our government must add its voice to an international choir, along with the governments of the United States, Japan, Britain, France, the whole world speaking together to Syria. Imagine how strong the voice will be.
We shall attain freedom for the Syrian Jews.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister. Today, the women of Canada are relieved, but not because of this government. For the past two years we have seen ministers of this government rise in their places and state unequivocally in this House that the silicone gel breast implant was a safe product. Yet time after time we in the opposition have brought forth the serious safety concerns of the scientific community and the women of Canada who have had these implants.
Can the Acting Prime Minister tell this House today and finally explain why this government has never, never come forward to ban this product in either a preliminary or a final way?

There are three categories of women that we have to serve. The first group is those who have had the breast implant and do not have any problems. If there is any problem, they should be referred to their doctors. Those who have problems with the breast implant should also go to their doctors and make a good decision in light of the information that they can share. The third one is the future of the breast implant. We have a moratorium. I said it will not be back on the market unless I have the assurance there is no problem. I believe my predecessor and I dealt with that issue the best we could. We are trying to do one thing and that is to help Canadian women to make the best decisions.

To the same minister, Mr. Speaker. After years of repeated requests, the minister finally tabled some documents in the House two days ago. I find it very odd that excluded from the package were four key studies I had already obtained under Access to Information from his own department. I find this is bordering on deception. This is totally unacceptable to me and the members on this side of the House.
Will the minister re-examine the situation carefully and table the full and comprehensive set of documents before the end of this week?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Mr. Speaker, what I said two days ago, and I repeat today, is that all documentation available in the Department of National Health and Welfare which is
not protected as private information is available and will be available. If there are any documents that my colleague has that were not in the package, it could be that because those documents were already public they were not presented in the package.

I ask the minister what specific action he intends to take today to go to the limit to sue Dow Coming to ensure that Canadian women are protected in this very important issue?

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, we have been as open with Canadians as the United States government is with Americans.

Nonsense and you know it. Read Bosley's report.
March 19, 1992

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
My friend at the other end says nonsense. Let me read what Mr. Gephardt, the majority leader of the House of Representatives said in a letter to Mrs. Hills. "While the U.S. negotiated position and documents have been provided to Canadian and Mexican negotiators, the public is being-that is the U.S. public-is being kept in the dark". Congress is asking for the same information as members on the other side are asking.
The simple facts are that we are not going to undermine our national negotiating position and we are not going to provide to members of the public on an open basis with matters which are subject of commercial confidentiality. We will continue to do the briefings on the basis I have offered to the House committee. That offer still stands. It is unfortunate that the members of the opposition have put politics ahead of their country's national interests.

Mr. Speaker, for two days in a row the Minister for International Trade has said that he would not offer commercially confidential information about the free trade negotiations. No one is asking for such information. No one is seeking commercially confidential information.
What Canadians want to know is what this government's minimal objectives are in these negotiations. For example, the existing United States-Canada free trade agreement has shown itself to be flawed because there is no definition of subsidies. Will this government be part of a trilateral agreement which does not include a subsidies code and which does not include a prompt and binding dispute settlement mechanism? That is the sort of question we want answered, not whether it is commercially confidential information.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I responded to that type of question quite precisely. The question of subsidies is the subject right now of negotiations under the multilateral trade negotiations. We have made it very clear it is the result of that negotiation that we will apply, both to the free trade agreement with the United States as well if we have one with Mexico, to the Mexican negotiations.
As far as the dispute settlement mechanism is concerned, my hon. friend is very well aware it was absolute-
Oral Questions
ly critical to our going through with the free trade agreement with the United States and the maintenance of that, on a binding basis, as my friend has reminded us, is also absolutely critical to a North American free trade negotiation.

The minister knows that those answers are the sort of questions which should be answered in committee in an open discussion and not in some sort of confidential briefing that is the best that the minister can apparently offer.
The Canadian people have many other questions that this government has failed to answer. Other countries, for example, Chile and Costa Rica, want to be part of a free trade agreement in the western hemisphere. Canadians will want to know whether it is one of the objectives of this government to open the way for other western hemisphere countries to join the agreement. Specifically, is this government seeking an accession clause in the final agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology

Precisely where we are going to end up on that particular issue I cannot say at this point, but I would be happy to go into it in more detail in the committee if he wishes to.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Deputy Prime Minister who will have noted that Helmut Kohl is flying to Washington tomorrow to discuss the German position at the renewed GATT discussions.

March 19, 1992
Oral Questions
Five weeks have passed since the Prime Minister was instructed unanimously by this House to hold similar meetings with Presidents Bush and Delore in order to secure their support for a clarified and strengthed article XI(2)(c)(i) at the GATT. Can he tell us what arrangements our Prime Minister has made to comply with that request?

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
The
Prime Minister, as the House knows and as farm leadership knows, has had discussions with international leaders, with Chancellor Kohl, with Prime Minister Major, with Prime Minister Mitterrand, with President Delore and with President Bush, putting forward Canada's position.
The Prime Minister spoke to Chancellor Kohl before his meeting this weekend with President Bush, putting forward Canada's position and attempting to garner support from Chancellor Kohl for Canada's position. We will continue to do that. It is a matter of the timing as to when it would best serve the interests of Canada that the Prime Minister take further steps, but the Prime Minister was deeply involved in this process well before the House instructed him. He was involved in the interests of Canadian agriculture over the whole round of GATT for the last five years.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, perhaps the minister would table in the House the dates of the meetings that he says occurred with President Bush and President Delors.
Mike Gifford, who was our senior negotiator at the GAIT talks told the publication Ontario Farmer that while Canada has not offered tariff equivalents for the supply managed industries, Canada's tabled offer has followed the Dunkel paper.
Since the Dunkel report does not mention anything about article XI(2)(c)(i), how is supply management protected with the government's position?

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is coming into the debate a little late.
We informed the supply management farm leaders, we informed the SAGIT, which advises the government, that when Canada tabled our access along with other countries, we would be following the Dunkel text with the exception of those industries which were supply managed.
We informed them that in fact we would be tabling no tariff equivalents for supply management but that we would in turn be tabling Canada's position which is to have supply management recognized, article XI recognized and operational or clarified and strengthened. We tabled that as Canada's position.
We have followed the Dunkel text with that exception. That was knowledge that was given to the SAGIT and supported by the SAGIT.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:

Considering the unprecedented loss of jobs following the signing of the free trade agreement between Canada and the United States, can the minister give this House the assurance that his government has completed the requisite impact studies to prove that an agreement with Mexico will not have the same disastrous consequences for Canada? speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

Mr. Speaker, let me just draw my friend's attention to the fact that our exports are up over $5 billion since we entered into the free trade agreement.
Our trade surplus with the United States is up about 10 per cent. The net flows of foreign direct investment have moved from a negative position of $2.5 billion to a net positive of about $5 billion or swinging $7.5 billion, all of which are helping this economy.
My hon. friend is cherry picking statistics when he talks about job loss. He is not looking at the net bottom line of what the positive benefits of this agreement are. As far as the impacts are concerned, I have commented on the impacts on a number of occasions.

March 19, 1992

We have two-way trade with Mexico of $2.5 billion. With the United'States, it is over $200 billion. If all trade is added in, it is $256 billion, so there is a tremendous difference. Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands-
Canso): Mr. Speaker, the minister cannot deny the thousands of job losses that have occurred by firms in Canada moving south of the border.
Surely Canadians have a right to know that they will not be sold down the river if Canada embarks upon a North American free trade agreement. speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me remind my friend again that some 70 per cent of the exports that come from Mexico into Canada come here free of duty already. There will not be the impact that my hon. friend is talking about.
My friend also talks about the job loss that he knows is directly caused by the free trade agreement. What any reasonable economist will tell you today is that there is a recession, there is adjustment related to free trade, there is adjustment related to change that is going on internationally that is affecting all countries.
It is this combination of things that is affecting our economy today. We are going through a period that is unprecedented in our history. For my hon. friend to draw these simplistic conclusions is misleading the Canadian public.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
The export tax imposed on tobacco products has caused great concern for the tobacco farmers in my riding, the riding of my colleague, the member for Oxford, and the riding of the member for Haldimand- Norfolk. At a time when farmers should be concerned about seeding their crops, many are wondering if they will have a market to sell to at harvest time.
While this measure was implemented to counter smuggling of tobacco products, farmers in my riding fear that this tax will put them and not the smugglers out of business.
Emotions are running high on this issue. Can the minister tell me what efforts the government has made to ensure that Canadian tobacco farmers will have a market for their 1992 crop?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the hon. member's concern and the concern of other hon. members. I particularly appreciate the fact that he and other members have made representations to me.
As the member indicated, the export tax was put in place to curtail the smuggling and the illegal entry of
Canadian cigarettes into Canada. I can assure the hon. member that it was never the intention of the export tax to be applied to legitimate exports of tobacco products into other countries. I can assure the hon. member that is the case and that is the intention. He can also assure tobacco farmers that the export tax was aimed at containing and smuggling and not applied to bona fide legitimate exports of tobacco products.
I can tell the hon. member that discussions are ongoing with the tobacco industry and I am satisfied that we will be able to resolve it in a manner satisfactory to the producers.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare. Was the minister stating his government's position when he said, and I quote the Canadian Press here: "Even if they have been asked to, francophones outside Quebec will not take part in the constitutional talks as natives will. There are a million Italians, but they do not ask for anything."
In his statement, the minister makes French Canadians and Acadians feel they are no more than one group among many others. In so doing, he wipes away an historical national policy and renounces linguistic duality. I ask him this: Was he quoted accurately?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Mr. Speaker, as a rule I do not comment on newspaper articles and today is no exception. I think that the House is a great forum and I take this opportunity to reiterate my opinion on that subject.
My position has not changed since the days when I was Secretary of State responsible for the issue of francophones outside Quebec for one year. The federal government is and will continue to be, responsible for the protection of all linguistic minorities in Canada. We have spent a lot of money on this and will continue in the future.
With regard to their participation in the constitutional talks, what I said, was that the number of people they represent does not constitute, in my mind, a criterion on which to decide whether or not a certain group should be represented, but rather that the francophone minority being represented though governments, with the Quebec government representing the francophone majority, while the federal government is responsible for the francophone minority, the representation of native groups is based on their existence as a founding nation.

March 19, 1992
Oral Questions
I have total respect for francophones outside Quebec, and this government continues and will continue in the future to protect their interests.

Mr. Speaker, I have a great deal of respect and affection for my Italian fellow citizens, but that is beside the point. I am not talking about minority language groups. I am talking about the Canadian duality.
I want the hon. minister to tell me whether he is stating government policy or not when he portrays the French Canadian community as nothing more than a minority like any other minority. I put the question to him.
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Mr. Speaker, I can only repeat what I said earlier. The francophone minority outside Quebec is part of one of this country's three founding nations, namely the francophone community, the majority of which is represented by the Quebec government, and the minority by the government of Canada.
That is my position and it reflects that of the government on this issue. The question was about representation at the constitutional table, and my answer was that it was not a matter of numbers. But I will say again, that I never comment on newspaper articles, and that is not about to change.
The hon. member for Saint-Denis wishes to ask a supplementary question.

I thank you, Mr. Speaker, for exceptionally allowing a second supplementary question.
The question of my colleague, who is probably the greatest expert in this House on such issues, was to find out from the minister whether or not he was misquoted. If he was, it is easy, let him tell us; if he does not believe he was misquoted, let him say so. But given the emotions aroused, there is enough emotion in this country and in my province, which is also his. This has nothing to do with our respect and friendship for our friends of Italian origin.
We want to know if from now on the French Canadian community is to be considered as one minority among
many others. That is what my colleague asked. This article stirred emotions and the minister must tell us whether or not it represents his views and that will allay our concerns about it.

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I must repeat what I said before.
The French-speaking community, whether it is in Quebec or not, is one of the founding peoples of this country. As such, it has a special status compared to other communities which are not called founding nations of Canada. As a majority, it is represented by the Government of Quebec in Quebec and as a minority, by the Government of Canada in the other provinces. Therefore it is up to the Government of Canada to fulfil that responsibility and role in the constitutional discussions and that is the position which I defended.
I have a great deal of respect for my colleague, who rarely asks questions and when he does, it is because he has some concern, I think. Therefore I repeat as honestly as I can that the French-speaking community, wherever it is, is a founding people of this country and as such, depending on its situation, must be defended accordingly. That is exactly what I did, and I will continue to do so, Mr. Speaker.

subtopic: FEDERAL-PROVINCIAL FISCAL ARRANGEMENTS AND FEDERAL POST-SECONDARY EDUCATION AND HEALTH CONTRIBUTIONS ACT MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I must say I am somewhat disappointed to be standing in this House once again to speak against the latest government budget, in particular when it comes to the transfer payments to the provinces.
The reason I say that is, as you know Mr. Speaker, if we are to follow the trend and look at the graphs as they relate to transfer payments for both post-secondary and health, by the year 2004 there will be no money going from the federal government to the provinces in the areas of post-secondary education and medicare.
Mr. Speaker, as you probably know, the issues of medicare and education have been identified by the Canadian people as the two most important issues and the issues that are closest to their hearts. The reason is because one of those issues, the question of education, deals with the future of Canadians and the other issue deals with their very existence, the issue of health and health care.
On the subject of education per se, Canada has spent perhaps more than any other country in the world. As a matter of fact, we spend approximately $50 billion on education. That includes all levels of government, federal, provincial and municipal.
When we look at the return on that investment, unfortunately we find it simply is not there. At no time has one level of government taken full control over the issue of education and rightly so because the question of education has always been a joint venture, a partnership between all the different levels of government. They have come together on this issue. The federal government deals with the transfer payments for education. It spends money on education through transfer payments and the provinces match those funds. From time to time they spend more and sometimes they spend less. The municipalities deal with questions of education at the primary and secondary level.
When one of those partners who is fully responsible knows full well that our education system is not meeting the needs, when one of those partners backs off, it really comes as a disappointment to the other partners. Like any other partnership, when one of the partners is not fulfilling his or her commitment, the partnership starts falling apart. That is exactly what is happening here in the area of education. More and more the federal government is backing away from its responsibility in the field of education.
There are two segments to it. First, historically when the federal government was investing money in the area of education in terms of transfer payments, it was giving that money to the provinces which in some cases were
March 19, 1992

not spending that money on education. They were spending it on other issues. That was one problem. In the past the federal government should have told the provinces that every dollar it was giving to education, it wanted to make sure that dollar was spent on education. It did not do so. As a result of that we have seen a deterioration in terms of investment at the provincial level in the areas of education.
At the present time, not only is the federal government not telling the provinces how it wants them to spend the money when it comes to education, the federal government is backing off on its commitment. Therefore, we are seeing less and less government funds going into the area of education.
That means that over the next decade or so, about 65 per cent of all jobs that will be created in Canada will require at least a grade 12 education. We are going to see a situation where we have less and less people who are equipped to enter the work force and be fully productive in our society.
Why do I say this? The statistics speak for themselves. Right now there is over a 30 per cent dropout rate at the post-secondary education level. In other words, one out of every three youths does not finish high school for whatever reason. That is one cause for alarm.
The other cause for alarm is the terrible question of illiteracy. The illiteracy rate here in Canada is extremely high. Approximately 38 per cent of Canadians are functionally illiterate. Compare that to a country such as Japan which has an illiteracy rate of about 5 per cent or to Germany which has an illiteracy rate of approximately 12 per cent or so. The conclusion is that there is something fundamentally wrong in terms of our society and how we deal with the question of illiteracy and the question of education.
It is interesting to know that not only is the question of education so important and so alarming when we look at the statistics, but at the same time, it is important when we look at the percentage of unemployed people. For ask instance, it has been found that if we have a group of people who have university degrees, we are likely to find that the unemployment rate is something around 10 per cent, which is in line with the national statistics. However, when we look at people who have a high school level of education, we find that the percentage of unemployment is somewhere around 16 per cent to 18 per cent.
Government Orders
When we look at the lower end of the scale, i.e., people who do not have a high school education, the percentage of unemployment in that particular segment of the population is somewhere around 24 per cent or 25 per cent.
It is not really difficult to see the correlation between a good education and good jobs. The more highly educated the work force or the population is, the better jobs they will get and the less unemployment we will find.
Having said all of that, there is also a lot to say about the health of the population. If a student, regardless of his or her age, goes to school hungry, it is highly unlikely he or she will learn as much as other children might learn if his or her stomach is full. The reason I say this is because we are finding more and more in schools all across the country that we have children who are going to school hungry.
That brings me to the second segment of my discussion and that is the transfer payments relating to health care, social assistance programs, social services and everything else. Every time the federal government cuts a dollar from the transfer payments to the provinces, do you know who feels it? The child on the street feels it. It is because the provinces in turn unload part of their responsibilities on to the municipalities. By unloading part of their responsibilities on to the municipalities, we are finding that more and more municipalities are unloading their responsibilities on to charitable organizations, non-profit organizations, church groups and special interest groups.
As a result of that, every level of government seems to be passing on its responsibility to someone else. Everything nowadays is falling on the school system and on the backs of the teachers in particular. Our teachers are now finding themselves as not only being teachers but also social workers, nurses, family planners, psychologists and food bank operators. In many of the urban centres in our society that is the kind of thing we are seeing on a daily basis.
What that tells me is that not only are we failing to do our job in the most effective way when it comes to dealing with the question of education, but we are also not providing the tools necessary for the people to do the work. We are not providing them with the necessary support that they deserve and they need.

Government Orders
While this particular budget per se did not specifically speak in terms of transfer payments, what we have seen in a way is a continuation of previous budgets. If we were to look at the budget of last year and the year before, the same thing happened.
What we are seeing is a decline on a regular basis in the area of transfer payments to the provinces. Those cuts are going to affect provinces such as Ontario, Alberta and British Columbia.
That brings me to the province of Ontario. Everything functions from a tax base. Everything is a function of the tax base. Not only in this province do we see that the transfer payments from the federal government are diminishing, but we also see the tax base shrinking.
Simply put, this province has been hit perhaps more than any other province when it comes to the shrinkage of its industry. It is partially because of the unfortunate policies of the government in the province of Ontario that does not take into consideration the need for business in order to survive, to provide jobs and employment. It is also because of the unfortunate recession that has hit at a most inappropriate time.
Looking at those two ends one asks: What can be done? Every time the provinces, the municipalities, the school system or any segment of our society fails the people, we as the federal government have the mandate to step in.
That is the thing that makes us so different as Canadians. We always seem to be on the lookout for those who need our help and assistance. I say this because we do have a crisis situation in our communities. We have a lot of children going to school hungry, people lining up in front of churches and food banks. There are a lot of people who lower their heads and look to charitable organizations for services and so on.
Seeing those kinds of situations, I cannot help but think that we must be doing something wrong. Somebody somewhere somehow in our society is doing something wrong. We as a federal government have the responsibility to take care of our people. We have to find out which level of government is not doing its work.
If we are saying that this government is doing a great job and putting the fundamentals in place and making sure that we have all of the special rules and laws that businesses might need in order to survive, then something else must be broken. It is up to this government to step in and find out what it really is that is broken.
When I look at what the government is doing in the area of transfer payments for education, I would say that the federal government is perhaps more guilty than the provinces, more guilty than the municipalities, more guilty than anyone else. In a way it is the main controller. It is the one sending the signals.
When the federal government sends the signal to the provinces by cutting transfer payments, surely the provinces are going to cut the transfer payments to the municipalities in the areas of education, social services and everything else.
As you can see, it is one problem that has triggered a series of other problems. If we are really serious about moving toward the future and creating a future for our children that is prosperous and good, that is maintained and contained, I suggest that we have to look at the fundamentals.
Those fundamentals are the investment in the futures of those people in the areas of education and health care. I cannot say enough on that. In particular, day after day we see people lining up in front of food banks and churches, people turning to special interest groups to get the support that they deserve and need.
With that I want to end with the statement that the government has a responsibility not only to reinstate those transfer payments, but also to make sure those transfer payments are increased with the cost of living as well as with the rate of inflation.
This is an important subject and I would like to bring to the attention of the House that unless we invest in the area of education there is no way we can solve our other problems. Unless we invest and combat illiteracy there is no way we can solve our other problems.
It does not matter whether we talk about unemployment, lack of productivity, lack of business, whatever. It does not matter how you slice it. The answer to all of that is education and education and education.
March 19, 1992

There is no question about it. If we have a properly educated workforce we can deal with just about anything. The pressure on our social programs will ease. The pressure on our health care system will ease. Political pressure will ease. All of those pressures seen on a daily basis will ease off.
Simply put, with an educated population we can do miracles. That will not only put Canada in the best position to be on the leading edge in the world community, but it will also ensure that Canada will remain on that leading edge.
I was watching a program about a week or so ago on television. It was on The Journal I think. The president of one of the Asian republics was asked about the difference between Canada and Singapore, or one of those countries and to compare the difference between North Americans and the Asian population. He used the correlation that the people in his country are like a high compression engine, while the workforce in North America is like a low compression engine.
I thought that correlation between the two was really interesting. If anything he was giving us a signal that while we might be great at creation and great at coming up with good new ideas, what is needed to be done is to streamline the system and make it efficient in order to improve the area of productivity.
I began by saying the only way to improve productivity is by increasing investment in education. What we are seeing right now is a lack of investment in the area of education.

Mr. Speaker, the member has dwelt at some length on all the social policy questions that attend the whole question of transfer payments to the provinces, et cetera, and the
Government Orders
way in which the federal government is cutting back on the provinces.
The member only came to this House in 1988 and I wonder if he is aware that the first unilateral cutback in federal transfer payments to the provinces happened under a Liberal government in 1982.
One of the things that has always disturbed me, amused me, and irritated me at times, is the fact that this trend toward the unilateral reduction of federal commitment in cost-sharing programs began under a Liberal government.
At the time the Conservative Party, when it was in opposition, railed against this unilateral violation of the federal-provincial agreement. It was thought to be a heinous act against co-operative federalism and, of course, it was. The only thing is that as soon as it came into power, no sooner than had it been in power, the then Minister of National Health and Welfare, the member for Provencher, one of his first acts was to unilaterally reduce EPF.
So I find it odd that Liberals and Conservatives should go at each other in this way when both are guilty of this, albeit the Conservatives, if you want to look at the world numerically, are more guilty in the sense that they have done it more often and that they have done it more severely in the sense that doing it more often adds up.
The fact of the matter is that the principle of the federal government unilaterally reducing federal transfer payments to the provinces was one established by the Liberal Minister of Finance, who now sits in the other place and who shall go unnamed.
Perhaps the Liberal Party has changed its mind. Perhaps it has repented of its earlier disposition toward federal-provincial programs. If that is so, we would like to see a confession, some repentance and then the member could speak freely about this new-found approach by the Liberal Party on federal-provincial fiscal arrangements.

I want to say this for the record. When the Prime Minister of this government made public his initiative on learning well, living well and the need for national objectives and so on in the area of education, that was something which my party supported wholeheartedly, the notion of national objectives for education and everything else.
Out of all the provinces in Canada, which province do you think was out in full force to oppose any kind of a national dialogue on the question of education? Guess. It was the province of Ontario.

One final word for the record, take the deficit as another example. We have a deficit let us say on an annual basis which is close to about $30 billion. Compare that to the province of Ontario. In one year, it jacked up the deficit to $11.5 billion which, per capita, probably is

The other thing I might mention just before I get into the substance of the bill is that the member in his diatribe against the Ontario NDP government talked about the Ontario NDP government raising tuition fees time after time after time after time. This just goes to show the exaggeration. The member must be a product of some educational system other than the excellent one that they have had in Ontario these years, or otherwise he would be able to count better than he was doing.
The Liberals cannot have it both ways. They cannot say that on the one hand everything that is happening in Ontario is the fault somehow of the Ontario NDP government and then, out of the other side of their mouths, talk about the free trade agreement when they talk about it. They do not like to talk about it much these days, but they do talk about it from time to time. Out of the other side of their mouths they cannot talk about the effect of cutbacks in EPF, for instances, to the provinces and pretend that that does not somehow affect all provinces including the Government of Ontario. On the same occasion in the House of Commons the member lamented cutbacks to EPF and the effect they would have on the provinces' ability to deliver programs. Yet, when it comes to talking about the ability of the Ontario NDP government to deliver programs, somehow that analysis fades, that analysis evaporates into the partisan political air, so to speak.
The fact is that these cutbacks in Established Programs Financing affect all provinces, and they have severely
Government Orders
affected Ontario in particular. Ontario is not protected in the same way as other provinces are by at least having some form of equalization payments. For the longest time Ontario has participated through the equalization payment scheme by supporting other provinces. Because Ontario has been hit so very hard by the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, it now finds itself in a position where it is being asked in this bill to continue for another two years to play the role economically in Confederation that it has played historically, when the economic conditions that pertain to Ontario have changed drastically.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was in the process of responding in part to the comments of the hon. member for Ottawa Centre when we were asked to go to the Senate for Royal Assent. One of the remaining things I wanted to comment on was the way he
thought it irrelevant that the Liberals were the first to unilaterally reduce federal transfer payments to the provinces. He thought this was just something of historical interest but did not have any relevance to the moment. I think this is a profound mistake. It is perhaps just a self-serving analysis but if it is held sincerely, it is a profound mistake.
I was trying to point out that when people are concerned about certain policy trends, if they are interested in changing those policy trends then they ought to know where those policy trends come from. The fact of the matter is that the unilateral reduction of federal transfer payments to the provinces has its origins in the Liberal government of 1982.
That is important. It is important in a number of other areas as well. The people are concerned about the free trade agreement. It would probably be useful for them to know that the free trade agreement has its origins in the Liberal government of that day when the royal commission set up by the Prime Minister of that time and headed up by a former Liberal Minister of Finance made the initial recommendation for a free trade agreement with the United States of America.
It is important if people are concerned about the effects of deregulation and transportation. They see the effects of deregulation and transportation and the negative consequences of that deregulation whether it is with respect to airlines, the current controversy about Nation-air, or the fact that soon we might have only one carrier when all this deregulation was supposed to produce competition rather than monopoly. They look at what has happened to our highways as a result of deregulation of the trucking industry, et cetera.
It is important if people are against this policy to know where this policy came from. Where did it have its beginnings? What is its origin? Its origin is in the dictum of a Liberal Minister of Transport who was the Minister of Transport in the Liberal government of 1980 to 1984 and who now sits on the opposition front benches in the person of the member for Winnipeg South Centre.
I say that if people are concerned about certain policies, then we have a responsibility in this House to be truthful and accurate in what the historical origins of that policy are when it comes to deregulation, the free trade agreement, and when it comes to unilateral reductions in federal transfer payments to the provinces as
March 19, 1992

well as a lot of other bad policies that were picked up, accelerated and in many cases made worse by the Conservatives. These policies had their origins with the Liberals.
One policy that did not have its origins with the Liberals as far as I know was the goods and services tax. This bill is very much about the goods and services tax. This is the other element of this bill that needs to be touched upon at this time. What this bill does in permitting the federal government in facilitating the collection of provincial sales tax by the federal government is to enable the federal government not to do just a harmless "we will help you out" kind of thing, tax harmonization, or whatever they want to call it.
The fact of the matter is that this bill is designed to help the federal government put pressure on the provinces to harmonize their sales tax systems with the goods and services tax. The federal government is saying to those provinces, the economies of which are bleeding as a result of cross-border shopping: "If you want us to stop that bleeding, if you want us to collect the provincial sales tax at the border, then what we want from you is a commitment to implement the harmonization of your sales tax system with the goods and services tax".
Therefore, many of the provinces are now run by governments the members of which ran in elections that were committed to non-harmonization of the GST with the provincial sales tax. They are now put into an incredible bind. They are being blackmailed by the federal government, a federal government which for its own purposes is willing to continue to see the blood letting go on.
It is willing to continue to see the various provincial economies being bled by cross-border shopping rather than doing the right thing and saying, given what this bill will enable it to do, to the provinces: "We are willing to collect your provincial sales tax regardless of whether or not you harmonize with the GST". That would be the right thing to do because it seems to me that the federal government should not use its ability to collect this tax, facilitated by this bill, as a lever against provinces which are responding to the democratically expressed will of
Government Orders
their own people with respect to whether or not those provinces should harmonize their tax system with the GST, and yet that is really what is going on.
The solution, of course, lies in none of this. The solution lies in getting rid of the GST in the first place. The solution lies in realizing that the GST has been a profound mistake with respect to tax fairness, in the way in which it places an extraordinary burden on the working poor and the middle-class in particular who are bearing the brunt of this tax and who, even before this tax, bore the brunt of paying the bills in this country. It is a profound mistake in terms of the over-all effect of the tax on the economy and particularly with respect to cross-border shopping and the fact that cross-border shopping has increased so significantly since the introduction of the GST.
The Minister of National Revenue likes to hide behind figures which simply show the number of trips that are made, although they are up significantly, but the figure that he does not like to look at very closely is how much more people are buying while they are down there. This shows that the increase in cross-border shopping is in the neighbourhood of 50 per cent or 60 per cent. It is a serious problem that all border communities and even some non-border communities are concerned about. It is part of a general malaise, if you like, that I think has been created in part by the free trade agreement.
The free trade agreement is not just an agreement, in spite of what the Prime Minister likes to say. It is not just a commercial agreement that we can cancel in six months if we like, although I think we should cancel it and an NDP government would cancel it. The fact of the matter is that it does tend to enshrine a particular world view. The world view that it enshrines is that there is no border.
Now if there is no border for corporations and if indeed there seems to be no border for governments, because we find more and more examples of provincial governments and even the federal government crossborder shopping, then what is the average Canadian to think? Is he or she expected to support the Canadian economy while their own governments do not?

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know how many times we have to rise in this Chamber and talk about the education system in this country. We seem to have been doing it year after year after year. Again today we have to look at what has happened to transfer payments.
My colleague from Winnipeg-Transcona is quite right that the cutback in transfer payments did not start with the present government but indeed started before they took office. That is not to say that it is right. It is not right. It was not right then. It is not right now.
I am not sure it is useful to analyse the past and look at what has happened in the past. The fact that the trend has continued is it seems to me more shameful rather than less. The effect of the cutbacks which indeed did start in the late 1970s and have continued up to the present time is disastrous not only for the whole country but particularly for disadvantaged parts of the country.
First of all my colleague from Ottawa who spoke earlier talked about the effect on secondary schools that have something like a 30 per cent drop-out rate all across the country.
This is what transfer payments are used for. Transfer payments to the provinces you can say go directly into secondary schools and help young people in schools to get the kind of high school education that they need.
The capping in a sense is a cutback. If you cap you are saying to the provinces they are not going to get the
increases expected and therefore those funds must be found in their own meagre and dwindling resources. A cap is in effect a cutback. You cannot stay still. You either go ahead or you go back. The effect of a cap is the same as a cutback. It is a cutback to secondary schools.
On top of that the provinces still have a cap on Established Programs Financing. In addition to the cut on transfer payments there is a consistent cut in Established Programs Financing which goes directly into post-secondary education and health. That is used to fund universities, community colleges, and post-secondary institutions. Those are finding the pinch and still find it today.
Third, the government in the budget made very little change in the Canada Student Loans program. It changed around the edges somewhat. It tinkered with the pay back of interest payments. But essentially it did not enrich the Canada Student Loans program. It gave no incentive and no help to young people who do not have the wherewithal to get a post-secondary education and need it desperately.
This is a time when training should be at the top of the agenda in this country and indeed is at the top of the agenda in every developed country in the world. It is at the top of the agenda in the United States. George Bush wanted to call himself the education president. It is at the top of the agenda in Great Britain. Margaret Thatcher, before she left, gave top priority to education and training.
If you look around the world, at Japan, Germany, countries that are making it today in the competitive global environment, they are putting training at the top of their agenda. You cannot have training without the foundation of education.
This is a time when you must put training at the top of the agenda. What is this government doing? It is talking a good game. It is setting up a national training board to give emphasis to training in this country.
But what happened after the budget came out? The co-chair of that national training board, Mr. Gerard Docquier, formerly a prominent, eminent and well-known and well-respected national president of the steelworkers in this country, criticized the government that appointed him to that board. And rightly so. What
March 19, 1992

this government has done is pay lip service to training. It has set up the national training board and brought in Bill C-21 to enrich the Unemployment Insurance Act to which it is no longer contributing. It is paying people who have unemployment insurance to get training, but if you do not, if you are in the work force and you need upgrading to take a new job, if you are about to be laid off and you want to upgrade to get new skills to take a new job, you are left out in the cold. Why? Because there is a hundred million cutback in this budget in the Canadian Jobs Strategy. A hundred million less in training dollars in this present budget.
Now that is on top of a hundred million less in the last budget. There was $200 million cut back in the Canadian Jobs Strategy Program for training in Canada for people who are on the job, for people who want to improve their skills, for employers who want to train their employees and cannot afford to do it themselves.
The government talks a good game in setting up a national training board, appointing eminent people to it and then it cuts the money. It consistently cuts the money in this country available for training, in the middle of a recession when companies cannot afford on their own to put their money into training and development. That is the kind of attitude we get and it is hypocrisy of the highest order. Countries around the world must be laughing at the kind of strategy that Canada is pursuing.
Who does this hurt most? It hurts most the disadvantaged in the country, whether they be individuals or whether they be regions. Let us take women, for example. In breaking through the glass ceiling, education and training has to be a top priority for any woman. Seventy per cent of all part-time students in this country are women. Single mothers who want to support themselves and who want to have a respectable place for themselves and their children in this country have to get education and training if they are really to have a life of their own and to become independent.
That is who this series of cutbacks affects. It affects women in this country and it affects single mothers
Government Orders
particularly. Who else does it affect? It affects native people. I might point out that on top of the cuts in transfer payments and the cuts in Established Programs Financing, the government also, a couple of years ago, capped the funds for post-secondary education for natives.
Natives are in exactly the same boat. If they are to have equality in this country, equality of opportunity, there has got to be funds provided for them for education and training. Unless they can get through high school, unless they can get through community colleges, unless they can get university degrees, there is no way the native people in this country are going to compete on an equal footing.
This budget and the last budget affects the disadvantaged. It affects disadvantaged regions because even a region like Ontario now is having difficulty in this country. We heard the debate earlier today about the difficulty and what the government of the day in Ontario has had to do. How much more difficulty is the government of Newfoundland finding itself in? We depend more heavily than anybody else on transfer payments. So places like the Atlantic are doubly hurt by this budget.
We say this again. I do not know how many times we have had to say this in the House and I do not quite understand why the policy is so. Surely, on the government side of the House, there must be the same opportunity to learn about what is needed, to learn about what is going on in other countries, to learn that education and training has to be a top priority in 1992. This government refuses to follow the practice in other developed countries in the world with which we are competing in the global economy, refuses to give education and training a priority. Not only that, but it consistently, in budget after budget, cuts back on the amount of funds available for education and training.
We are going to vote against this bill when it comes forward. We are going to keep saying what we have been saying today as long as we have to up to and until the time that we become the government of Canada. Then we have to rectify the mistakes that the hon. member for Winnipeg-Transcona referred to in his remarks.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is a very serious subject. I want to speak on this and at the outset to say how much I appreciated the comments from the hon. member for Labrador who has a lot of credibility in this area. He is a professional educator and is well known in Newfoundland for the work he has done on education. I may say that his family is from a group of educators. His brother is a doctor at Memorial University whom I know quite well. You might say that the entire family has been dedicated to the education of Newfoundlanders.
I appreciate the conviction with which the hon. member spoke. I wish I had the wide range of knowledge that he has on the subject. I detected in his delivery a great and compassionate concern for those who are being educated. We all share that with him. We could not substantiate it as well. It is with conviction that we speak on the lack of appreciation. I do have a certain compassion for the budget difficulties.
It is after all a question of priorities. We, as a country, have been told time and time again that there are solutions to the problem of competitiveness, which is a buzz word but it is a very important word these days. In order to be competitive, we have to do a number of things. We hire Harvard professors to tell us this. We do government studies to do this. The answer is always the same. We know what the problem is. The problem is that we need to be focusing more of our attention or giving better priority to the scientists and to science and technology, research and development. We need to be focusing more on education.
Anything that I have seen in the last year or so on the subject leads me to believe that somebody is not paying attention to the requirement to focus our attention and to look at the priorities.
We are looking at 5 million young Canadians who every year go to school in primary and secondary education. We are looking at 68 universities. We are looking at close to 530,000 post-secondary education students and we are looking for, as the hon. member for Ottawa Centre said, somewhere in the vicinity of a $45 billion to $50 billion expenditure. That is roughly the same that we spend on health. That is a large chunk of money if you look at the money as a total allocation.
I see that as an input, but what do I see as an output? I see, as the hon. member for Labrador mentioned, a 30 per cent high school drop-out rate in secondary education. For 10 young Canadians who start grade nine education, seven of them will graduate from high school. That is only part of the problem. For those seven out of the 10 who graduate, only 72 per cent of them will go on to formalized training, not just post-secondary education in a university, but apprenticeship training or vocational colleges.
You may say that 72 per cent is not bad. It is greater than 50 per cent. When you compare that to the United States, the equivalent number is 87 per cent and in Japan, it is 92 per cent. We are really off the mark on that one.
What else do I see? I see a reduction in the amount of money we are putting in research and development. We have one of the lowest inputs either per capita or as a percentage of our GNP. No matter how you look at the statistics, our record is far from brilliant and it is getting less brilliant every year.
March 19, 1992

What are we doing with education? With this dismal record of high school drop-outs and a very poor record compared with our competitors in the United States and Japan-and I could quote other statistics for Germany, Sweden and other parts of the world, but I think I make my point on that-we are cutting back on educational allowances to those provinces in particular that can least afford to absorb that kind of a monstrous cut.
Two or three speakers ago talked about the province of Ontario. There is no question but that it does have a problem and I sympathize with it. However, in the province of Newfoundland where I come from transfers to the provincial government make up 50 per cent of the budget. If money is cut from education it has to be found somewhere, particularly when the money in education is grouped with another high priority item like health care. They do not give a lot of hope for either the future of competitiveness or the future of health care.
I would be prepared to get into a debate in this House any time about what the priority items should be in our country. But all along one has been health care. We have had the best record in the world in health care. In education, I do not think it has been quite as good, but we have always had Canadians whom we could have been proud of in the field of education, in science and in technology.
I want to give some idea of how proud that record was. Getting into the real world and the world that I know a lot more about than education, I recall as a naval officer the innovations that were brought about by scientists who were associated with the navy during World War II and post war. They resulted in the development of some innovative features that are being used by all countries. I will give a couple of examples.
First was the development of a variable depth sonar. It allowed a sound transfuser to get below the sound gradients that are always present in the water. Essentially it allowed submarines to be detected at 10 to 20 times what they normally could be detected at with a sonar mounted in the hull of the ship.
That was developed by two Canadian scientists who worked for the naval research establishment during World War II. I am very proud that I happened to have known the family of one of those scientists. The variable depth sonar from World War II took roughly 10 years to develop. The prototype was developed, tested and put
Government Orders
into production by Canada. Practically every navy of the world, even the Soviets when they were our fiercest enemy, employed exactly that scientific knowledge and prototype to conduct their naval operations.
Similarly with helicopters at sea. The haul-down mechanism was used and is used in practically all navies now. The rapid securing device for a helicopter that operates from a smaller ship than an aircraft carrier, a frigate or a destroyer, was totally designed, conceived, tested, trialed and produced in Canada.
Those are two examples of the things that made us competitive with the rest of the world. We were more than competitive; we were winners in that regard.
With the record we have examined, what we have seen in the last five or six years, and what we project for the future, I wonder if we will be able to have politicians who can stand in the House of Commons and boast about these kinds of achievements? I fear that the answer may not be in the affirmative.
I do not like this bill. I do not like the reduction in moneys, and I do not like the way the money for provinces that can least afford to absorb the costs is being cut back.
As a final note, this is a very timely subject for me because I met this morning with a professional educator from Newfoundland. He was here to speak as a Newfoundlander but not on education in Newfoundland. He has a Ph.D. in education and he talked about education from a federal viewpoint. Mr. Speaker, if you think the hon. member for Labrador and I are concerned by the presentations we have put forward, I can assure you it would seem very mild compared with the concern shown by the gentleman and his colleague in my office this morning. Both of them are on education boards, are professional educators and are involved day after day after day. It is their livelihood. They are very concerned.
I would ask the government to reconsider, refocus and repriorize so that education and health gets more importance.
